text: Expression of Constitutively Active Akt , Rescues Necroptosis Under Serum Free Conditions

We used L929 cells stably expressing constitutively active wild type <extra_id_0> Akt1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) or the catalytically inactive mutant <extra_id_0> K179M <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> in order to further understand the contribution of growth factors and <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase to Akt activation during necroptosis .

Constitutively active <extra_id_0> Akt1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) was generated as previously described [ 37 ] by the addition of a myristoylation signal which provides constitutive localization to the plasma membrane and by the deletion of the auto - inhibitory PH domain ( Fig . 7A ) resulting in an Akt that is active under serum free .

It is important to note that the cells expressing <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> were viable , grew in a manner indistinguishable from the empty vector control cells , and were not triggered to induce necroptosis by serum starvation ( Fig . 7B ) .
This indicates that active Akt alone is not sufficient to induce necroptotic cell death .

Under serum free conditions <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not the <extra_id_0> K179M <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant , fully restored zVAD.fmk - induced necroptosis ( Fig . 7A , B ) .
Nec-1 prevented both <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> dependent cell death and the necroptosis - specific delayed increase in Akt Thr308 phosphorylation ( Fig . 7B , C ) .

Myr-Akt also allowed other zVAD.fmk - dependent events , including activation of JNK and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> phosphorylation ( Fig . 7C ) and upregulation of <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA ( Fig . 7D ) to occur under serum free conditions , confirming an important role for Akt at the apex of necroptotic signaling .
These data demonstrated that the presence of active and membrane localized Akt is sufficient to uncouple Akt activation during necroptosis from growth factor signaling .

<extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase was still able to regulate Akt activation during necroptosis , suggesting that growth factors and <extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase provide two independent inputs required for Akt changes during necroptosis .

<extra_id_0> RIP1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> kinase - dependent Thr308 phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> during necroptosis increased <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> activity as it did with endogenous Akt ( Fig . 5 ) .

Phosphorylation of many previously described Akt substrates was increased upon the expression of <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , but not the <extra_id_0> K179M <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mutant , confirming that these molecules are Akt substrates in L929 cells ( Fig . 7C ) .
The effect of zVAD.fmk on their phosphorylation varied , likely due to the increased basal activity of <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

Some substrates , including <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> S6 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , GSK-3 and <extra_id_0> FoxO4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , were fully phosphorylated even in the absence of zVAD.fmk .

On the other hand , phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> FoxO1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> MDM2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was significantly increased in the presence of zVAD.fmk , indicating that necroptotic Thr308 phosphorylation of <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> still promoted its activity .

Under serum free conditions all zVAD.fmk - induced downstream events ( cell death , JNK activation , <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> production ) were dependent on the over expressed <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .
This allowed us to examine the effects of other Akt mutations on necroptosis .
First , we found that membrane localization of Akt is required .

Full length Akt or a mutant lacking both the PH domain and the Myr tag did not support the activation of cell death or increased Thr308 phosphorylation following zVAD.fmk addition under serum free conditions ( Fig .
S8A , B ) .
Second , we found a specific and critical role for Thr308 phosphorylation in the regulation of the necroptotic functions of Akt .

It has been reported that Ala mutations at Thr308 and Ser473 cause a reduction in the catalytic activity of <extra_id_0> Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , while Asp mutants increase activity [ 38 ] .
We examined the effect of Ala and Asp mutants at both sites during necroptosis .
In our hands , both Asp mutants displayed activity comparable to wild type Akt , while both Ala mutants displayed comparable decreases in activity ( Fig .
S8C ) .
Despite similar catalytic activities , Thr308 and Ser473 mutants displayed major differences in their ability to promote necroptotic changes ( Fig . 7E , F , G ) .

As expected , the <extra_id_0> S473D mutant <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , which was phosphorylated on Thr308 after the addition of zVAD , displayed only slightly reduced activity , while <extra_id_0> S473A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was significantly less active in all aspects of necroptosis .

<extra_id_0> S473A <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> was unable to be efficiently phosphorylated on Thr308 possibly due to the inability of the Ala mutated 473 site to be phosphorylated and provide a docking site for <extra_id_0> PDK1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> to phosphorylate Thr308 [ 39 ] .

Strikingly , both Ala and Asp mutants of Thr308 were significantly less active in promoting cell death , phosphorylation of JNK and <extra_id_0> c-Jun <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> mRNA .

This suggests that <extra_id_0> T308D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , in spite of being an active Akt construct , may not be a perfect mimic of phosphorylation and this mutant form of the kinase may not have sufficient activity to phosphorylate the entire repertoire of substrates in the cells .

When tested , <extra_id_0> T308D <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> did not support the downstream phosphorylation of several substrates that were phosphorylated by the <extra_id_0> Myr-Akt <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> construct in the presence of zVAD including <extra_id_0> FoxO1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> Foxo4 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , <extra_id_0> MDM2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , and <extra_id_0> p70S6K <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( Fig .
S8D ) .

Our model , based on these results , is that necroptosis - specific Thr308 phosphorylation provides a critical link between necroptotic machinery and Akt kinase , allowing Akt to phosphorylate substrates during necroptosis , promote <extra_id_0> TNFalpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> synthesis , JNK activation and eventual cell death .
